bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Morris Fishbein, February 23, 1926

div1.p: Laura Carter sends photographs to Fishbein for his article on Henry Carter.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Morris Fishbein, February 23, 1926
div1.opener:
, D. C.,
February 23, 1926.
Dr. Morris Fishbein,
Editor, HYGEIA,
American Medical Association,
535 North Dearborn Street,
Chicago, Illinois.
Dear Doctor Fishbein:
div1.p:
I am enclosing, in accordance with your request in your letter of
February 18th. a picture of Ship Island Quarantine Station. This
sketch is the only picture of Ship Island in the possession of the U. S.
Public Health Service so I must request that absolutely no changes be
made in it (by deepening lines etc) for purposes of reproduction and
that, in case it cannot be used as it is that it be sent back to the
Library of the Service at your earliest convenience. Of course, one
could photograph the sketch and retouch the resultant plate with the
sketch as a model by which to “check up.”

I am also enclosing a photograph of Fort Jefferson. The Dry Tor-
tugas, of which place you published two pictures in Father's article
in HYGEIA.

With best wishes to yourself and HYGEIA and trusting that these
enclosures will be of use to you.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter 2 enclosures.
P. S. I shall be grateful if you will please return these the
pictures by registered mail (return receipt desired) as soon as you
have copied them, since, as you readily understand, the Library thinks
a great deal of them.
L. A. C.
